gov.sandia.rbb.ui
Class RBBReplayControl

java.lang.Object
  gov.sandia.rbb.RBBEventListener.Adapter
      gov.sandia.rbb.ui.RBBReplayControl
All Implemented Interfaces:
RBBEventListener
public class RBBReplayControl
extends RBBEventListener.Adapter

synchronization using an RBB Timeseries.

The tagset of the ts event is type=timeControl

The ts has one observation. Its columns are:
TIME: system time. (stored in TIME because it's a double, and system time is generally the milliseconds since the UNIX Epoch, i.e. a big number)
C1: sim time
C2: replay rate
C3: a random number that is the SenderID, used to break feedback loops.

This class allows multiple replayers to stay in sync so long as their system clocks are synchronized (e.g. using ntp). The key is that the current sim time is computed on demand as the time since replay was commanded times the replay speed.

Field Detail

timeTags

public static final java.lang.String timeTags
This tagset must uniquely identify the timeseries that will be used to synchronize the RBB Replay Control Transport.

By changing the tags, it should be possible to have multiple sets of synchronized times in the same RBB

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

RBBReplayControl

public RBBReplayControl(RBB rbb,
                        RBBReplayControl.Listener listener,
                        java.lang.Integer animationMs)
                 throws java.sql.SQLException
Connect this transport to the specified RBB.

The listener will be notified when the replay state is modified, or the current play rate is nonzero and animationMS milliseconds have passed. Call disconnect() to disable this transport before the end of the program, Until disconnect() is called, the process will keeping listening and responding to updates indefinitely. (The RBB must be in another process for this to work).

Note, this actually connects the transport to the database underlying the RBB instance; the java RBB object instance can go away, or be disconnected from the underlying database, etc. yet the transport will still work.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

Method Detail

set

public void set(java.lang.Long newSystemTime,
                java.lang.Long newSimTime,
                java.lang.Double newPlayRate,
                boolean updateRBB)
         throws java.sql.SQLException
Parameters:
newSystemTime: - may be (and normally will be) null, if so it is set to the current system time.
newSimTime: - may be null, if so it is set to getSimTime()
newPlayRate: - may be null, if so it is left at what it was before.
updateRBB: - If called by application code this is normally specified as true, which means to send the new replay state to other listeners of the RBB and NOT notify the listener of this ReplayControl instance (normally the caller) (the RBB update notification is ignored when receive in response to update by self).
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

This is called internally by the code and not needed by users of the class. This is called from the Swing update thread (only!)

disconnect

public void disconnect()
dissassociate from the RBB. we do not rbb.disconnect() because we never did rbb.connect() - the rbb is just handed to us.

eventDataAdded

public void eventDataAdded(RBB rbb,
                           RBBEventChange.DataAdded ec)
Users of this class don't call this. It is called by the RBB as a notification that somebody set the replay state, by a dedicated notification thread created by the RBB
